content:
SHORT TITLE, FINDINGS. The Act titled "Fire Safe Cigarette Act of 1998" aims to address the significant issue of cigarette ignited fires in the United States, which have resulted in numerous deaths, injuries, and property damage. The Congress recognizes the need for a cigarette fire safety standard to prevent such incidents, especially those involving children. The previous acts in 1984 and 1990 have laid the groundwork for this standard. The most recent study by the Consumer Product Safety Commission found that the cost of the loss of human life and personal property from not having a cigarette fire safety standard is $4,000,000,000 a year. It is appropriate for the Consumer Product Safety Commission to implement a cigarette fire safety standard. SEC. 2. CIGARETTE FIRE SAFETY STANDARD. The Consumer Product Safety Commission must issue a cigarette fire safety standard within 18 months to reduce ignition risk. They must consult with relevant agencies and consider existing low ignition propensity cigarettes. The Consumer Product Safety Commission must issue a cigarette fire safety standard within 18 months to reduce ignition risk. The rule will prohibit stockpiling of cigarettes not meeting the standard. Stockpiling is defined as manufacturing or importing cigarettes at a higher rate than the previous year leading up to the standard issuance. The rule will be issued following the procedures outlined in section 553 of title 5, United States Code, and certain provisions of the Consumer Product Safety Act will not apply to the proceedings. The Consumer Product Safety Commission must issue a cigarette fire safety standard within 18 months to reduce ignition risk. The rule will prohibit stockpiling of cigarettes not meeting the standard. Certain provisions of the Consumer Product Safety Act will not apply to the proceedings under this subsection. The effective date of the rule issued must not be later than 30 months after the enactment of this Act. Any person affected by the rule may file a petition for judicial review within 60 days of the rule issuance. The Commission must file the record of proceedings with the court. If additional evidence is needed, the court may allow it to be presented before the Commission. The Commission can then modify or make new findings based on the additional evidence. The Commission can modify or make new findings based on additional evidence presented before the court, which then has jurisdiction to review the Commission's rule in accordance with chapter 7 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 3. ENFORCEMENT. Prohibits manufacturing or importing non-compliant cigarettes and failing to provide required information. Violations are considered under the Consumer Product Safety Act. 

SEC. 4. PREEMPTION. This Act and its standards do not affect more stringent state laws. Compliance with standards cannot be used as a defense in civil actions.

SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "Commission" refers to the Consumer Product Safety Commission, and "cigarette" is defined as per the Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act.
